page.title: 17A WOOD IN GREAT BROMLEY
page.content: There are several small woods in the area.Typical of these is{Boudge {Hill Wood.}Ground cover is so thick it is often impenetrable, comprising thorns,nettles,thistles and brambles. {Trees}are mostly{oak, ash, silver {birch, larch, spruce and pine}with {poplars}ringing the wood. The conifers appear to have been planted but the deciduous trees are for the most part naturalised. The wood has two distinct characteristics; the western end is much older with many silver birches and old oaks; the eastern end is mostly firs, ash, and younger oaks. { }The{wood}is used for{game}and is not public,{pheasants}being reared in one corner. The wood provides cover for {rabbits, magpies and wood-pigeons.}It is close to the new Elmstead by-pass road and when this was built an {underpass was provided for badgers.}
